Florence Dempster.Action: Appears visibly intoxicated, leads a mongrel dog into a professional setting, blows a cheap noisemaker to get attention.
Enters the composing room obviously tipsy, leads a mongrel dog, and blows a cheap tin horn to get attention.
Her humorous and lively entrance causes men to laugh, indicating some degree of social confidence and ability to engage others.
Jokes warmly with others, invites them to drink and be merry, engages playfully with the dog and group.
Teases the managing editor (Hard-Tack) but with a tone that suggests camaraderie rather than hostility.
Casually jokes and maintains a lighthearted atmosphere among colleagues, even when tensions are high.
Confidently approaches the managing editor’s office despite knowing he is upset, showing resolve.
Avoids confrontation verbally by saying she doesn't want to see Hard-Tack, indicating some emotional defensiveness.
Puts her arm over the editor's shoulder in a teasing manner despite his anger.
Responds sarcastically and with edge to the editor's comments, showing frustration.
Engages in somewhat playful banter despite tense situation.
Sarcastically questions editor about news source, showing sharpness but also defensiveness.
Attempts to charm and control editor by putting arm over his shoulder, but is rejected.
Responds quickly and assertively to editor's harsh words, showing some confidence.
Responds to the editor's anger with sarcasm and humor.
Calls her dog away from a man she distrusts because he has been reading naughty stories.
Enters police station with gay, almost rowdy camaraderie and thumps one of the officers on the back, greeting him warmly.
Teases the sergeant about his sex life after grabbing the magazine out of his hand.
Shows unenthusiastic, somewhat dismissive attitude toward the suicide story, indicating detachment.
Enters police station confidently, interacts familiarly with officers, tries to engage and gather news despite being fired.
Shows lack of enthusiasm or fresh insight about a potential news story (unenthusiastic about Joan Gale's suicide).
Responds to news about a suicide with initial lack of concern but becomes interested and engaged when murder is suggested.
Threatens the sergeant when she suspects he might be joking or misleading her about a suspect.
Expresses enthusiasm at a potential lead ('Hotcha! Saved, one job!').
Politely asks the sergeant not to share the information with others and thanks him when promised exclusivity.
Shows prompt enthusiasm upon learning a key lead and immediately tries to act on it by reaching for the telephone to follow up.
Demonstrates some guardedness and urgency by telling the sergeant not to share the information with anyone else, indicating an understanding of sensitive information control.
Gets startled and threatens the sergeant when she suspects he might be stringing her, showing a sharp and defensive reaction rather than naïve acceptance.
Shows confidence and control by throwing the switch to leave the room in darkness as she exits, possibly to protect the information or maintain an upper hand.
Presses glass of ice water to forehead and temple before drinking, indicating awareness and attempt to calm nerves.
Admits having 'case of jitters' but comments on the urgency of the case, indicating some self-awareness and realism.
Makes a sarcastic joke about the missing body to lighten the mood.
Mocks the operator on the phone with sarcasm.
Makes sarcastic, flippant remarks during a serious situation, which leads to a negative reaction from detectives.
Attempts to take initiative by quickly using the telephone to make a call after the body is found missing.
Introduces herself professionally and calmly to Winton despite his distressed state.
Sits beside Winton and tries to comfort him with a gentle pat and reassuring words about innocence.
Maintains composure and follows Winton when he becomes agitated, placing a hand on his shoulder to steady him.
Places hand on Winton's shoulder and speaks firmly but without kindness, calls him 'cry-baby', pushes him aggressively for information.
Shows some concern by engaging Winton and pressing for truth despite his distress.
Firmly challenges Winton's emotional display to get to the facts and pushes him to provide concrete information about the Dale girl and his actions.
Uses a somewhat brusque tone ('cry-baby') which may alienate rather than comfort, possibly undermining rapport and information gathering.
Reassures Winton, pats him on the shoulder, encourages him to stay strong.
Attempts to help Winton by explaining the situation gently despite his nervousness.
Expresses sympathy for Winton, calling him a poor kid getting a raw deal.
Keeps focus on the case and calmly explains important facts despite tense atmosphere.
Reassures Winton and encourages him to stay confident during interrogation.
Is perceptive about Winton's nervousness but remains composed and helpful.
Makes a strategic statement to the editor suggesting awareness of the social dynamics affecting the case.
Advocates giving George Winton a break despite pressure to condemn him.
Expresses anger and frustration with the editor’s harsh attitude.
Declares she won’t pursue the story from an angle that she finds unjust.
Argues logically that the missing body case should be considered in light of multiple similar recent thefts, demonstrating reasoning and insight.
Insists on advocating for the accused (George Winton) despite opposition, showing conviction and willingness to challenge bias.
Does not waver under the Editor's cynical dismissal and maintains her stance, indicating confidence and assertiveness.
Ends discussion abruptly by refusing to work on the case from the presumptive angle, which might limit her adaptability or cooperation.
Insists on handling the case her way despite editor's objections, quits in protest.
Admits Winton is scared, hysterical, dumb, and worthless but shows some sympathy by acknowledging his fear and hysteria.
Teases Charlotte sarcastically about Ralph, jokes about money and jail with a lighthearted tone.
Engages in light-hearted sarcastic banter with Charlotte, showing social awareness but no particular skill or decisiveness.
Effortlessly shifts from casual conversation to singing a tune about a jail inmate smoothly, indicating a confident and quick-thinking nature.
Amusedly engages in conversation with Charlotte, showing no hostility.
Dismisses romantic feelings as insincere, cynical about love.
Expresses preference for a life of excitement and money over domesticity.
Makes a sarcastic remark about appearance and wealth being key, implying shallow values.
Engages in witty, confident conversation about love and money, showing quick thinking and self-assuredness.
Stops to pay the taxi driver promptly and efficiently, demonstrating responsibility and social awareness.
Responds briefly and calmly to Ralph's greeting and disappointment without complaint, showing composure.
Walks up toward museum door and looks attentively through glass at interior, observing carefully.
Does not question Ralph's explanation or try to negotiate timing, appears passive.
Detains Ralph by the arm with excitement, proposing to slip in and give the museum a look-over to help with publicity.
Dismisses Ralph's concern about the old man's temper and confidently insists she can charm him using her 'sex appeal' and calls him a 'pushover' with a playful attitude.
Attempts to enter museum despite prohibition, uses informal, friendly language ('Aw, listen, Beaver').
Takes advantage of introduction to slip away and inspect figures carefully, avoiding suspicion.
Attempts to enter the museum despite clear prohibition, speaks out of turn, interrupted curtly.
Takes advantage of an introduction distraction to slip away and carefully observe multiple figures, focusing on the Joan Gale figure.
Takes Charlotte by the arm in a friendly, lively manner and suggests going out to eat together.
Jokingly says to Igor, 'So long, Pop, see you in jail,' which may imply a teasing rather than sincere warmth.
Abruptly leaves Charlotte to go to her office, ignoring Charlotte's concern about lunch.
Greets editor confidently and asks directly to see original pictures of Joan Gale.
Engages excitedly in conversation with the editor, showing enthusiasm but also impatience (tells editor to keep his trap shut).
Asks to see original pictures and insists she is right after examining them, then explains her scoop excitedly and confidently to the editor.
Raises voice indignantly but playfully calls the editor 'poor baboon'; shows humor and a teasing friendliness.
Engages in casual banter and teases the editor about his past marriage with a joking tone.
Insists on investigating suspicious circumstances despite being dismissed; demonstrates determination rather than warmth.
Speculates about the wax figure theory based on observation and logical connection (body stolen, death mask, wax mold).
Dismisses the editor's skepticism and insists on investigating the suspicious wax museum despite lack of concrete proof.
Shows indignation but uses humor effectively in response to editor's sarcasm.
Continues to trust her own judgment despite being told her theory is likely wrong; laughs confidently and bets on being right.
Refuses to reconsider or adjust her opinion even when presented with evidence that undermines her theory.
Calls Winton to cheer him up and encourages him positively to do himself a good turn.
Calls Winton and lightheartedly teases him, showing social confidence and the ability to lighten a tense situation.
Gives Winton clear, direct instructions to meet at a specific time and place, indicating planning and decisiveness.
Encourages Charlotte in a friendly, playful manner ('Come on, beautiful').
Admits hunger and fatigue honestly, showing openness about her needs.
Casually discusses her appointment with young Winton and speaks of money pragmatically, showing a somewhat cynical, self-interested attitude.
Displays disregard for discretion when talking about relationships and money, ignoring Charlotte's displeasure.
Expresses relief and lightly jokes about Charlotte's dress, easing social tension.
Secretly inspects the wax figure by sticking a pin into its arm to confirm suspicion, acting stealthily.
Politely compliments Igor's artwork and expresses genuine interest in specific pieces.
Interrupts a private conversation to join in with polite remarks.
Asks questions to understand more about the creation of the works, showing curiosity and engagement.
Engages thoughtfully with Igor about the wax figures, notices lighting improvements, asks insightful questions about specific works and their creators.
Interrupts a private conversation between Igor and Charlotte without hesitation, showing social confidence.
Expresses curiosity and a desire to understand the creation process behind the figures, demonstrating intellectual engagement.
Shows agitated concern in looking after Sparrow as he leaves.
Waves cheerfully at Winton when he honks his horn.
Shows agitated concern while watching Sparrow leave, indicating awareness and emotional reaction to potential issues.
Decides to leave companions to meet a date, taking initiative and confidently communicating this decision.
Urges Winton to hurry and tail Sparrow, showing eagerness to pursue a lead
Commands the driver to hurry and tail a suspect, showing initiative and urgency.
Advises not to ask questions yet, indicating she has a plan or insight about the situation.
Tells Winton the news about the robbery, shares information openly as one of the interested parties.
Encourages Winton to consider doing detective work despite his reluctance, appears persistent but supportive.
Refuses to involve the police to avoid sensationalizing the event, shows concern for discretion.
Implies sarcasm toward Winton ('nice warm place'), but seems more teasing than cruel.
Insists on investigating the situation herself, showing determination and engagement.
Insists on handling the situation discreetly to avoid sensationalism, takes initiative by directing Winton to drive her around the corner to get a closer look.
Acts decisively by jumping out of the car and affirming her plan despite Winton's reluctance.
Cautiously tries the locked basement door, peeks through windows, climbs through cautiously to enter Basement to investigate.
Startled by her reflection in the mirror, trips and reacts with fear.
Hides behind a box upon seeing the Monster’s reflection and presence, showing fear and caution.
Glances quickly up and down the street before cautiously trying the basement door and then trying another way in by opening a window and climbing through.
Feels her way about the dark basement, but is startled by her own reflection in the mirror, trips and sits down heavily on a coffin box, gasping and springing to her feet terrified.
Clambers through basement window and hurries up stairs despite fright.
Sways and almost falls on reaching the top of the stairs.
Runs directly to police and reports finding the body, showing presence of mind and courage.
Speaks hysterically initially when reporting discovery.
Seriously insists police verify her claim themselves, indicating confidence and rationality.
Tears loose from detective trying to take her away and insists on involvement in the case, showing determination and assertiveness.
Uses sarcastic remarks towards the detective but also shows confidence by presenting her credentials.

Tears loose from detective's attempt to remove her, insists on investigating the story herself and demands to be considered an assistant on the case, shows credentials asserting her right to be present.
Provides a descriptive and vivid account of the creature she saw, acknowledging the uncertainty but helping the investigation.
Admits that her description is 'not very good,' showing some lack of precision or confidence in observation.
Points out the box containing Joan Gale promptly upon entering the basement.
Almost falls over a smaller box in her effort to get away.
Expresses eagerness for a drink playfully, wiggling fingers and smiling amid a tense situation, encouraging laughter.
Expresses a craving for gin in a lighthearted, somewhat childish manner, sinking down on a box and wiggling fingers; does not take any active steps in the investigation or situation.
Keeps the bottles of whiskey for her 'percentage' despite being told to put them back, showing a self-serving stance.
Laughs off her embarrassment sincerely with others, showing openness about her feelings.
Boldly claims a share of the whiskey found, asserting control and confidence despite the situation.
Finds the 'dump' of whiskey by tailing a corpse, demonstrating resourcefulness and initiative.
Expresses embarrassment over tailing a corpse and discovering contraband, showing some social self-awareness but slight awkwardness.
Jokes about her managing editor being 'poison' and laughs with the Captain.
Politely indicates that she will leave after the arrest, showing social ease.
Recognizes poison in managing editor with humor and apparent familiarity.
Decides to leave after handling a major police matter, indicating awareness of timing and situation.
Admits ignorance honestly about the watch and does not attempt to mislead the officers.
Encourages action against a suspect by supporting the captain's decision.
Shows spirited, daring behavior by urging speeding and taking chances while driving; interacts playfully with Winton.
Jokes warmly with Winton despite seriousness—playful and forgiving tone about his sudden love.
Quickly engages with editor, extending hand and showing enthusiasm for a story.
Refuses to reveal details of story fearing previous disclosures caused trouble.
Decides to get out and take a taxi when the driver is careless, showing assertiveness and practical decision-making.
Engages in witty banter while assessing Winton's proposal by asking about his money, demonstrating shrewdness and grounded thinking.
Enters the editor's office breathless and confidently presents she has a strong story, showing initiative and confidence in her professional role.
Refuses to reveal details of her story to the editor for fear it will go haywire, indicating cautiousness but also some lack of trust or hesitation in collaboration.
Steps toward editor belligerently and insists on her involvement despite teasing.
Uses hostile language ('soap bubble', 'make you eat dirt') toward the editor.
Confidently insists on being involved in the story despite skepticism from the editor.
Challenges and pushes the editor with belligerence but stays focused on her goal.
Throws insults and makes threats in frustration, which may undermine professionalism.
No direct actions or statements by Florence in the excerpt; presence is implied but no demonstrated skill or intelligence.
Approaches Ralph friendly and politely, asking permission to look around the factory for a story that might help the 'old gent'.
Approaches Ralph at the museum late at night, directly asks to look around the factory, showing initiative and persistence to get a story.
Disregards Ralph's suggestion to wait for the old man and insists on going in immediately, demonstrating confidence and decisiveness.
Tries to help the 'old gent' by building a special Sunday Magazine story to boost his spirits, doing it quietly without telling him, believing he's worth the effort.
Jokingly threatens Winton to not deceive her or she'll come back and haunt him, displaying a friendly and teasing manner.
Tries to build a special Sunday Magazine story to help the old gent, showing initiative and thoughtful planning.
Decides to do her work without telling the old gent, showing discretion and confidence in her judgment.
Observes the wax figures carefully comparing multiple angles to identify a likeness, demonstrating attention to detail and analytical skill.
Studies the photo and wax figure carefully, noticing the identical features between the man and Voltaire's figure.
Nervously bites her fingernails while analyzing the evidence and hesitates, showing anxiety.
Discreetly waits for Hugo to pass before showing Ralph the photograph to discuss suspicions quietly, demonstrating caution and awareness.
Ignores Ralph's teasing remark about nail biting, remaining focused on the task at hand.
Hears scream and immediately rushes to stairs with Ralph, taking quick action to investigate.
Finds door locked but proceeds to attempt entry with Ralph, showing decisiveness and willingness to act under pressure.
Standing at trap, looking down horrified and then running upstairs screaming for help.
Appears at head of stairs, runs to Winton and urgently urges him to come help without hesitation.
Urges Winton to do something to help, showing concern in a crisis.
Runs through crowd with Winton, showing urgency to provide assistance or escape.
Breathlessly urges Winton to drive quickly, displaying determination and reliance on others.
Panic and urge Winton to do something instead of taking control herself.
Runs toward the museum screaming, drawing attention and help.
Immediately runs through the crowd to catch up with Winton and scramble into his car, urging him urgently to get her uptown without stopping for traffic lights.
Plays along with colleagues' playful praise, laughs and jokes with them
Responds indignantly and insultingly to editor's negative feedback
Ignoring editor's romantic suggestion, grins teasingly
Typing frantically to complete a major story, delivers it on time despite exhaustion.
Receives praise from colleagues for a significant scoop, shows confidence in her work.
Engages in banter and defends her work against editor's harsh critique with indignation and wit.
Reacting to editor’s proposal with a grin, not seriously entertaining it.
